conclusion: The v-t graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time.
The acceleration of the particle is the rate of change of its velocity with respect to time, which is the slope of the v-t graph.
We are interested in the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
Looking at the graph, the segment of the graph between t=1s and t=3s is a straight line.
This indicates that the acceleration is constant during this time interval.
To find the acceleration, we need to calculate the slope of this straight line.
We can choose any two points on this line segment.
Let's choose the endpoints of the interval.
At t = 1 second, the velocity is v = 2 m/s.
So, the first point is (t_1, v_1) = (1, 2).
At t = 3 seconds, the velocity is v = -2 m/s.
So, the second point is (t_2, v_2) = (3, -2).
The acceleration a is the slope of the line, which is given by the change in velocity divided by the change in time.
Substituting the coordinates of the two points, we get: a = (-2 m/s - 2 m/s)/(3 s - 1 s)
So, the acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is -2 m/s^2.
